item.description:
A mancala game. From Mancala.Wikia.com:

Adji-boto ("pebble boat") is a mancala game which is played by the Saramaccans who live on the upper Saramacca river in Suriname. The Saramaccans are a tribe of Bush-Negroes which was formed by escaped slaves. The first field study on the game was conducted by the American ethnologue Melville J. Herskovits (1895-1963) in 1928 in the village of Beidotti. The game resembles mancala games known in Benin, West Africa.

The game is used to entertain the dead during the ten-day period preceding burial in the kre wosu, or house of mourning. The play is only carried out during the daylight hours because in the night the yorkas, or ghosts of the dead, would come and play with us and eventually carry away our spirits.

The boards are only carved by old widowed men because this is a serious issue. They are made in two shapes, those having straight tops, and those in which the tops are curved. A village should have both types, so that if a person was fond of one kind of board dies, the people can play for a time on the other and there will be a lessened danger of his ghost coming to play with them. Although the Bush-Negroes are fine wood-carvers the Saramacca boards are of the roughest. This is because of the sacred character of the game which is not one which can be hurried in playing. It must entail some effort and even pain to bring it to perfection.

Rules
Adji-boto is played on a board called adji-bangi ("pebble stool") that consists of 2x5=10 holes. In addition, each player has a store called boto ("boat") at his right hand.

Each hole contains 10 stones called adji ("pebbles") at the start of the game.

Each turn a player distributes the contents of one of his holes, except one stone that remains in the hole, one by one, in consecutive holes in an anti-clockwise direction.

In the first ten moves of the game all of the ten playing holes must be played.

It is only permitted to play a hole which contains at least two stones.

It is not allowed to pass a move unless a player has no legal move left.

If the last stone ends (kaba) in a hole which precedes another hole or a continuous chain of holes that contains one, three or five stones (including any sequential combinations), these stones are captured and put into the player's boto. It is possible to capture on either side of the board. The only exception is the opening move in which nothing is captured. If a Bush-Negro captures he says: "I eat your children!" (Mi nyam yu p'kin kaba!)

The game is finished when both players can't move.

The remaining stones are captured by the player on whose side they are.

The player who has won most stones is declared winner. It is said that "the loser is killed!" (a kiri mi kaba!).

If both players captured the same number of stones the game is a draw.

item.description:
Published in 1963 by "Circular Checkers, Inc." in Newfoundland, New Jersey, "The Sisti Challenge" is a Checkers variant. The publisher provided a round board consisting of 37 circles arranged in four concentric rings and split among two colours, and two sets of checkers (12 in each colour). As in traditional Checkers, the players' goal is to capture the opponents' checkers or to force the opponent into a position in which any legal move will allow the moving piece to be captured.

The rules approximate traditional checkers, with only six circles in the outermost ring serving as "Kinging Circles." (These are the three rings for each colour that are farthest removed on the board from the opponent's home territory.)

The construction of the playing area into a series of rings comprised of circles creates the necessity of several unique rules, specifically redefining "forward movement" (the motion of a checker toward its opponent's central kinging circle, the "Rules of the Nearest Circle" in movement and jumping that define which circles a checker may move to from its current position, and a "Single Combination Jump" which allows one checker jumping another within its ring to change directions and end in a separate ring.

Who Knows is 'an intellectual and exciting game' published by John Jaques & Sons, London around 1930. There is a bag full of questions (Where is Long Island? Off the coast of New York.) and a set of cards with divisions on to place those you get right. The winner is the player who fills his card first (36 right answers)

Thanks to ebayer gljacobsct for info on this game

Touchdown from Milton Bradley (There is a NAVY Pennant on the game board but the box title is simply Touchdown) comes with 1 spinner dial numbered 1 to 6, one head linesmen piece and 1 Milton Bradley Football Playing board.. Players spin the dial to kick off. After placing the ball on a square according to directions in squares one to six, the head linesman piece is placed 20 squares ahead of the ball. Each square represent ½ a yard with the object being to gain 10 yards or twenty squares within 4 spins. If a player should not succeed in advancing the ball 10 yards in 4 downs, the opponent takes possession of the ball. If the ball lands upon a square marked “opponent offside” no count of that down is taken. Should the ball land for two successive spins upon “forward pass incomplete" within a period of 4 downs the spinner is penalized 5 yards or 10 squares. The squares of the game have results in them which direct the person spinning the spinner to go to different squares on the board which might add yards or cause a fumble or score a touchdown.

Players lay Siege to each others cities and castle in order to be the first to recover their royal family.

Using one or more decks of normal playing cards (depending on number of players), each year of conflict is broken up into seasons where cards are used to attack, populate your castle or defend your walls.

Rules for the game are available on the author's website here-
http://www.curufea.com/games/siege.php

Object -

Be the first player to fill the 12 bins in his letter case with properly Zip Coded letters. This is done by rolling dice and drawing letters.

Summary of play -

Players each chooses a letter case bin (1 of the 4 different colors) each has a unique zip code, then each player is dealt a starting hand of letters. These letters are sorted into a players bin if they have the correct corresponding zip code. All other letters are placed face down in front of each of the players.

On a turn a player rolls two non standard dice. One with colors and the other is numbered 1, 2, or 3. The color rolled determines the pile of letters a player will draw from the number determines how many letters are drawn.

First player to fill his bin wins the game.

name.value: Age of Muskets Volume III: Vienna or Death

item.description:
"Vienna or Death" is the third volume in our “Age of Muskets” series and it can be played together with Volume II "Eagles Rising". It depicts the campaigns that took place during 1796-1797 and again in 1799-1800 in southern Germany, the Rhine and Danube river areas and northern Switzerland. As in Volume II, it's a two-in-one game since the first group of scenarios show the brilliant campaign of 1796 of Archduke Charles of Austria, who defeated and expelled from Germany the French Armies that had launched an invasion across the Rhine; and it also includes other scenarios centered on the Swiss-German side of the Austro-Russian offensive of 1799. They depict the Allied advance into Switzerland and the Alps and their defeat that culminated in the outstanding victory of the French troops led by Moreau at Hohenlinden.

As in Volume I the game includes all the elements that characterized pre-industrial warfare. However, the player will also find some elements distinctive of this campaign, as Alpine terrain, a different map and time scale to reflect the duration of the campaign as well as special rules to play the longest campaign scenarios together with those of Volume II "Eagles Rising". Given the size of the armies involved most of the scenarios of this Volume are quite adequate for two to four players since there are few headquarters and their size is quite manageable.

Each game contains:
- 2 80x60 cm maps (together form a 60x160 cm map of Switzerland and Southern Germany) 
- 8 Terrain overlays used in field battles 
- 2 Sets of Player Aid Sheets (3 sheets each)
- 2 General Headquarters display sheets
- 2 Dice (d10)
- 1 Set of Army Sheets (to be photocopied) 
- 832 counters (4 sheets)
- 1 Age of Muskets series booklet
- 1 Vienna or Death Exclusive Rules booklet, scenarios, historical and designer notes
"Vienna or Death" is more than just a game. It comes with 6 introductory battle scenarios –Wurzburg, Neresheim, Schliengen, Ostrach, Stockach, Hohenlinden- to learn the battle rules and 11 campaign scenarios of increasing complexity. From the first ("Mountain warfare" lasting four turns) to the whole campaigns of 1796-97 and 1799-1800. Furthermore, there are scenarios to be played using volumes II and III together to play both campaigns on the three fronts, Germany, Switzerland and Italy!!!

El juego está en inglés pero encontrarás en esta página (Apoyo al Jugador) los archivos en español necesarios para jugar –Hojas de Ayuda, Reglas y Escenarios.

The Game of "WYT"
Will You Triumph?

The game has a space theme unrelated to the game play.

The board is made of alternating black and white triangles.

Each players controls one set of 10 pieces subdivided into four types that each move a different number of triangles.

The goal of the game is to move your Grydmaster(King) to the board's center square. All of a player's pieces are set up on one side of the board.

Each turn, a player selects one piece to move. He may capture by landing on an opponent's piece. If he captures an opponent's Grydmaster he gets to control all of that player's pieces.

A interesting touch: a die is included only to determine the start player.

name.value: High Stakes Fast Action at the Track

item.description: High Stakes is a game of thoroughbred horse racing. There are 11 horses in the race, along with four other "scratch" horses. Four "scratch" cards are drawn to remove 4 horses and replace them with penalty horses. The deck is then reshuffled and players are dealt a hand of cards from the 44. Players are given an equal amount of 5 point chips, and they each ante into the Winner's Circle. Roll the dice and move that horse forward one space, if you roll a penalty horse you pay the penalty in chips. The race is over when one horse crosses the finish line. Every player with that horse's number takes an equal share. If you hold more then one, you get multiple shares.

DEEP INTO THE BEKAA
Final Confrontation, 1000 hrs, June 11, 1982

DEEP INTO THE BEKAA is a simulation depicting the first T-72 and Merkava tank battles in the final stages and hours of the Peace for Galilee Israeli offensive in 1982. These tank battles were the largest of the war and occurred as both sides sought to position themselves before the ceasefire at noon. They began at 10 a.m. as the Israeli Merkava tanks moved deep into the Bekaa Valley from their 77th battalion and the 409th Anti-tank (TOWs on Jeeps) swept far to the north until both collided with the fresh Syrian T-72 tanks of the 82nd Brigade, 3rd Armor Division.
As soon as elements of the Merkava tank battalion arrived, Syrian T-72 tanks began to fire from a distance of 2500-3000 yds. The Israelis inched ever closer to the Syrian border and in desperation, Syrian Milan AT units and Gazelle TOW gunships began to appear. To the Israeli, the going was a cautious advance yet one that had to achieve the most territory before the agreed ceasefire at Noon. The battle is unique for it was the first time the new Russian T-72 tank faced off with the new Israeli Merkava, for both their debut in battle.

Units represent single AFVs, helicopters or infantry AT teams. Each hex measures 324 yards from side to side. Each turn represents 5 min. time.

The game comes with a 11x17" map, 280 counters, rules.

We Can Be Heroes II is a wargaming rule set for people who want fun games. The rules have a focus on interactive lighthearted play, so don't bring your poker face to the game.

Play is based around the adventures of heroes (or heroines) and their companions (Sidekicks), as they battle through one-off or linked scenarios.

Although intended for 25-28mm individual figures, the game will work with any scale of miniatures. It is also very versatile and can recreate games at many levels from small skirmish to large scale battles with mutli-based miniatures in any period.

There are rules to get you gaming a variety of periods from fantasy, sci-fi, WW2 & Vietnam.

WCBH2 contains many helpful examples of play, guides, and thoughts on the application and spirit of the rules.

It is suitable for solo or multiple players.

Includes printable quick reference cards, character information and equipment cards.

A Leader of Men is a miniature wargame capturing Company-level combat in WW2 and more recent wars. It uses a new and unique system to remove a high degree of control from players, but allows them to play the role of Leaders trying to direct and control the battle situation. Players will get intensely involved in the game as the battles developed and are shaped by the Leaders the player represents.

The rules include all you need to start playing except for the equipment listed in the rules, miniatures, and scenery. The book is 118 pages in an A4 format.

· Rules covering combat during WW2 with many helpful examples of play, guides, and thoughts on the application.
· Six generic scenarios for two players.
· A solo play scenario.
· A guide to major armies in Europe during WW2.
· A selection of Army lists for the major combatants with individual Army Quick Reference Sheets.
· A Quick Reference page for the rules.
· Army List note pages to record the important details of your army in an easy to use format.

A noun, an adjective and a letter are flipped open, and all players need to find a word that matches all three components by shouting out a profound or silly association. There are several variants of this included in the rule sheet.
The players use drinking straws to blow their little sailboats towards a finish line. The sailboats have a rounded wooden hull and a plastic sail and are difficult to control.

Cash Cab is a loose adaptation of a television quiz game.

The players choose a destination on the gameboard which represents Manhattan. As the players' "cab" moves towards the destination, the players answer trivia questions to win money. A "Red Light Challenge" can add to the players' winnings if they can name enough items that fit the given category in thirty seconds. The players win if they can get enough right answers by the time their "cab" reaches its destination. Three wrong answers before the destination is reached and the players lose.

item.description:
"Keep your musket loaded!"

Song of Drums and Shakos is a fast play Napoleonic skirmish game based on the popular *Song of Blades and Heroes* mechanics. This is a stand-alone product - you do not need Song of Blades and Heroes to play this game.

Muster your squad. Deploy your soldiers and fire volleys at the enemy...and when the moment of truth comes, fix bayonets and charge!

- Three scenarios included
- Simple, elegant system where your tactical decisions matter
- playable in any scale with single based models
- All major troop types represented: 160+ profiles (French, British,
Prussian, Russian, and Austrian)
- Easy measuring system
- No bookkeeping
- Point system for building up your Squad
- Play with as little as 5-6 elite to 20 inexperienced soldiers in a
standard game
- Playable on a small table (60x60 cm for 15mm)
- Simple yet subtle command system, with Officers and NCO
- Two or more players, 30-45 minutes for a full game
- Ideal introductory rule set to small actions in the Napoleonic Era.

item.description: Card game where you ask geography questions on the cards. A correct answer will get you the card. If no one can answer your question, you keep the card. The person with the most cards win.

A card game of collecting sets of historical Presidential Cabinets. The Presidential Cabinet at the time consisted of Secretary of State, Secretary of Treasury, and Secretary of War. The player that collects the most Cabinets wins.

The each card has background information about the person.

From the publisher's web site:

It's silly, it's fun, it's the classic trading game... gone stupid!

Welcome to Stupidopoly, where you'll be racing your friends around the board, buying your favorite characters and watching the big bucks roll in! But look out, you might find yourself STUCK IN THE TOILET. (Phew!)

It sounds easy, but you'll be the one looking stupid if you're the first player to go broke!

It's the classic trading game...gone stupid!

name.value: Boys are Stupid, Throw Rocks at Them!

item.description:
From the publisher's web site:

But first you must collect them! Just answer the wacky questions to pick up enough rocks and race back to your home base to win the game. But watch out, other players may steal your rocks by challenging you to a throw-off.

So what are you waiting for? Pick up the dice and let's find out who has the best throw!

Strategy Cup Soccer is the thinking man's game of soccer. You, the coach, must select your players and devise a winning strategy.

No matter who you are in the soccer community, this game will bring you challenging soccer action match after match.

The soccer coach can use Strategy Cup Soccer to develop that winning strategy. The soccer player can use Strategy Cup Soccer to better his understanding of the player's role on the field. The soccer fan will no longer have to be content watching because you call the shots!

Strategy Cup Soccer includes a full color gameboard, die-cut pieces, easy to use Action Tables, complete rules booklet, and score pads. Everything you need to create your own soccer match simulation is in this box."

In Sprawl, players buy cards to add to their individual cities. The cards represent city blocks that advantage the players in different ways. Some cards earn players money (which score at the end of every round except the last), some are strictly population (which are only scored at the end of the game) and others are a combination of the two. Price is determined by the rolling of dice, more dice are rolled with every round as the game progresses. The winner is the player with the most populous city at the end of the 5th round of play. The game involves bidding, tile placement and big pay-offs each round.

From the publisher's website:

Ragnarok is Upon Us!

You gaze across the once peaceful lands as you strap on your heavy armor and weapons. The leather creaks and steel clangs as you gird yourself for war. Overhead, storm clouds gather and the lightning slams into the earth in great forking bolts all around you. A howling north wind scourers the lands clean in preparation for the final conflict that will decide the fate of the world.

You know in your heart that of all the battles that have come before, this will be the last, and greatest. This is Ragnarok, the final battle between the gods of men and the dark forces of the night.

With a wave of your massive hand you summon forth the heroes and Valkyrie that will fight at your side. The ground trembles under the footsteps of your mighty foes. There they are! On the horizon, grim giants, fell beasts, and the undead of countless battlefields approach in unending waves. Above the clatter of their weapons and armor a clear deep note pierces the sky. It is Heimdall’s horn! He is calling forth the gods and heroes to stand fast at the rainbow Bifrost Bridge and do battle.

Without hesitation, you stride forward to stand at his side with your brothers and sisters. You are an Aesir, a god and defender of humanity, and this is the time of legends!

Game Play…

A few years ago, we realized that the core action-reaction card mechanic of Down In Flames would also be perfect for other interactive combat situations, but we could never think of the right setting. Finally, a couple months ago, we came up with the idea of designing a game based on the Norse gods, their foes the Jotun, and the mythical battle to end all battles, Ragnarok. In this game, we’ve given the action-reaction system a twist in that the turn sequence is interactive, so as each attack is played, the next card played is actually a counter-attack that can inflict damage. This makes for a very intense battle system where every card can both attack and defend.

In this fact-paced card game, you take on the role of one of Norse mythologies greater gods such as Thor, Odin, Heimdall, or one of their Jotun enemies like Thrym, Fenrir, or Loki.

Once you are girded for battle, you will hack, slash, thrust, and grapple your way to victory!

Ragnarok is designed and packaged to be an economical social game. Instead of our normal 9” x 12” box, this game comes in a 4” x 6” box. This is an ideal game for people who would like to socialize while playing a game. Each game takes only 30 to 60 minutes, so the game play is fast and furious.

The game’s components are designed to be language independent. The card titles are in English, but all the other game information is represented with iconic symbols and numbers.

Scheduled Components: 
110 Full color cards (63mm x 88mm)
1 Full color counter sheet
Rulebook (Full Color)

Players: 2 to 6 
Play Time: 30 minutes
Complexity: Low

from the website:
Daemornia: Battlegrounds is a game of skirmishes between rival factions. It takes place using a series of cards depicting creatures, scenarios, equipment, skills, events and more. It is played between two or more players using a deck of 40 cards each and requires a degree of tactical thinking in selecting the right force. Through careful deployment and equipping your warriors the objective is to defeat your opponent through winning battles, raids and capturing scenarios.

Trivia Fever is a simple trivia game designed to be played with or without an Apple II.

If used with your Apple, then it takes care of picking questions and answers. If you use the book, then the players have to choose the questions using a spinner and keep track of the scores on the provided scorepad.

It was also released for the Tandy Color computer.

This is a TCG designed and made in Singapore.

Players are Pirates trying to win the game by either sinking an opponent's ship or plundering it to reduce the booty deck to 0 cards.

There are three types of cards: ship cards, booty cards and battle cards (used to attack and plunder opponent's ships).

The first set features three factions. There is currently organized tournament play in Singapore and Malaysia.

Home Page: http://www.menatsea.com/
Goal of the game is to give snails a home. This is done by playing cards out of your hand faster than the others.

Place Your Verse, described as "a 'Know Your Bible' game" on the box, is a card game where players attempt to match dealt cards with bible verses under their correct headings. A winner is determined based on score, where players gain points for correct matches and lose points for incorrect ones. There are also "strays" which match no heading but players can still win points by naming the verse, or lose points by playing them incorrectly. Although specified for 2-6 players, the instructions state that larger groups may participate by playing as teams, using the same rules.

In Thailand, There is an attempt to create boardgames that use the Thai alphabet in a Scrabble like game and its name is Kham Khom (à¸„à¸³à¸„à¸¡ - meaning: epigram)

Instead of using 26 English - Latin letters, the game uses the Thai alphabet. The Thai alphabet has 44 consonants , 20 vowels, 4 Diacritics and some symbols that are necessary in usage. The game uses only 42 consonants (At present, 2 of the 44 are dropped from being used) and drawn vowel tiles can be set aside and then can be played anytime in the turn without drawing.

The rules of Kham Khom is some slightly different from Scrabble because the Thai alphabet has a more complex system than the English - Latin alphabet.

item.description: Modified from the classic word game, Scrabble. A-Math game uses the same mechanisms but employs mathematical equations instead of letters. The players will play mathematical digits and operators tiles to lay down the equation.

At the Gates of Loyang is a trading game in which you are able to produce goods by planting them and later selling them to customers. You can use the abilities of some helpers to increase your income or production.

Fields, customers, helpers, and miscellaneous objects are represented by cards. Each player receives two of these cards per round distributed by a bidding/drawing mechanism in which you end up with one of the cards you draw and one of the cards of a public offer filled by all players. Additionally, to these cards you always receive one field for free each round.

Placing one good on a field fills the complete field with goods of this type. Each round, one unit per field is harvested. After planting, harvesting, and distributing cards, each player can use as many actions as he wants, only limited by the number of his cards or the number of goods he owns. At the end of his turn, he can invest the earned money on a scoring track, where early money is worth more than late money. The game ends after a certain number of rounds, and the player who is first on the scoring track wins.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
Merkator is about the rise of Hamburg after the Thirty Years' War.

You visit cities to collect goods or fulfill orders. The collected goods are added to the cities when a player visits a neighboring city. Fulfilling an order provides you with another better, but more complex order additional to the fulfilled order which you keep and can fulfill again, although the number of orders you can own is limited. Each order itself is worth a certain amount of points at the end of the game. Also you can exchange these points for special cards which provide additional goods in certain cities or more victory points if you fulfill certain conditions at game end.

Depending on the city you want to enter you either receive a resource called "time" or you have to spend it. By paying a certain time-fee you are allowed to accompany another player on his trip to a town to fulfill your orders in this town (but not to collect goods). The game ends when a player receives the order with the highest value by fulfilling the order one level below.

item.description:
All-time Baseball is a simulation in which participants select teams from 500 of the greatest Major League baseball players of all time (1871 through the present). Then they play a single game, a series of games, or an entire schedule. Each player is represented in the game by a card, with his performance based on his real-life statistics. The stats used include batting, power, bunting, fielding, throwing, speed, pitching, and more. Pitchers tire, and (in series or league play) must rest a certain number of days after pitching.

How well would Ty Cobb have hit Roger Clemens? Would Sandy Koufax have often struck out The Babe? Could Lou Brock have stolen many bases against Ivan Rodriguez' powerful arm? Would Brooks Robinson have robbed Tony Gwynn of many hits? Play All-time Baseball with your friends and find out!

The game uses the same overall system as Sports Illustrated Superstar Baseball!, from which it is derived, but with hundreds of added players and a host of other refinements.

Indunas Colonels and Emirs, created by Rudy Scott Nelson, is a 1:10 scale based miniatures game set in the British Colonial period of the late 19th century (1850 to 1900). Much of the information is centered around their African campaigns.

The movie Khartoum and the fights between the British and the Mahdi is a good exemplar of the time period for these rules.

It uses a unique set of leadership rules, which perhaps is overdone, but also provides some degree of humor to the game.

Apparently Mr. Nelson revised and re-released this game in 2000

Fans of Chess and Arimaa will want to pay close attention to The Travelers, a game which has not been commercially produced, but probably should be.

The game, played on a 9×9 board, is explained as "an unorthodox game, very different from Western Chess. It is a strange game, but it is very nice, and regardless the apparent simplicity of some pieces and rules, it is a very complex and deep game. The object of the game is to move TWO pieces, called TRAVELERS, to the last rank," according to information found on www.chessvariants.org.

The pieces include:


 Travelers (T): Can move in the eight directions, up-to three positions. A Traveler can't capture pieces, neither being captured. A Traveler can't move into Check, but if in Check, it is not obligatory that you move your Traveler. When a Traveler reaches the last rank, it can't move, neither being displaced. You win the game if your two Travelers reach the last rank.
 Displacer (D): Can move as Queens. If a Displacer lands on a square orthogonally adjacent to an enemy piece, you can DISPLACE the enemy piece (except a Block) and send it to ANY EMPTY square in the vertical line or the horizontal line defined by the Displacer's landing square. A Displacer can't displace a Traveler that has reached the last rank.
 Block (B): Moves in the eight directions, up-to-three squares. A Block can't capture, neither being captured. Block can't be displaced. A Block can't never move to the first or to the last rank.
 Ace (1): Moves in the eight directions, up-to-three squares. An Ace can capture a piece at distance 1 in the eight directions, except a Traveler or a Block.
 Deuce (2): Moves in the eight directions, up-to-three squares. A Deuce can capture a piece at distance exactly 2 in the eight directions, regardless there is or not an intermediate piece in the path. They can't capture Travelers or Blocks.
 Trey (3): Moves in the eight directions, up-to-three squares. A Trey can capture a piece at distance exactly 3 in the eight directions, regardless there are or not intermediate pieces in the path. They can't capture Travelers or Blocks. 


You start the games with two Travelers, one Displacer, one Block, four Aces, two Deuces and two treys.

From the publisher's website:

"Travel through the Kingdom of Speech to save the princess from the ferocious dragon! Using their knightly word skills, students will be tested and tried to complete various tasks relating to application and usage of nouns, verbs, adjectives, adverbs, pronouns, prepositions, interjections, and conjunctions. Those who truly know the 8 parts of speech are sure to return the princess safely to the castle! Game Includes: die, pawns, 160 game cards, tri-fold game board, and game story card."

Ages 8 and up.

Link to publisher's page:
http://www.learningwelled.com/c/@Uh5DSnlAEAxkI/Pages/product.html?nocache@24+record@4363WCL

Created as a gift for the 2008 chit chat gift exchange.

A fantastic game that accurately simulates a day spent in chit chat!

In other words: a completely random waste of time.

Players take turns rolling dice and collecting cards to see who can waste more time in chit chat during their work day.

We Built This City is a city building game where each player is vying to construct various public buildings throughout a walled, port city. Resources arrive each turn and are bid upon by all of the players, and these resources are then used to construct the available buildings. Victory points are awarded according to the building value and there are additional victory points awarded both during the game and at the games end.

The combination of player interaction and multiple game mechanics makes this a fun, challenging and ever-changing game.

Beta versions are available for play-testing now. Please contact support@ogagames.com to find out how your club or group can order a copy for review.

Warstone, a collectible card game that adds the unique dimension of Warstone marbles to a game that includes the appeal of card collecting and strategic thinking. The marbles add elements of manual dexterity and sharp-shooting skills to the game, which as far as the marbles are concerned, can be played for keeps or not.

Home Page: http://www.warstone.com/

LoYo! is an ingenious combination of Strategy, Risk, Memorization and Luck! But most of all, it is fun, easy to learn and quick play for family and friends.

The object of the game is to have the lowest score at the end of six rounds of play. Each player receives four face-down cards. After glancing at any two cards. Players pull cards numbered 1 to 9 and two specialty cards LoYo (zero) and OH NO! (fifteen) from the deck or dead pile and replace with their cards.

Players try to get LoYo! cards and avoid the dreaded OH NO! cards. When you think you have the lowest score, shout "LoYo" to roll the dice and get a bonus deduction or add to your opponent ... But watch out! Someone may catch you and double your score! Feel like giving up? Don't worry, there's LoYo! Catch-Up, that rewards a triple bonus value of the dice in order to "Catch-Up".

There are two other versions that can be incorporated to add greater complexity to original game. So, if you feel like taking more risk? Add LoYo! Challenge. This feature challenges all players to a potential "all in poker show down" at the beginning of each round. Also, if you want a mind boggling experience try LoYo! Headache, which utilizes six cards.

Be one of the first persons to play this quick playing game craze that combines the best of poker, Concentration, Uno and then some. LoYo! is sure to be a favorite of yours for years to come.

Take a peek at www.loyogame.com or www.amazon.com search word ...loyo game.

Reiner Knizia's Ingenious series got a new child in late 2008: Einfach Genial: Das Kartenspiel ("Ingenious: The Card Game"). In this game, a player receives a hand of six cards, with one card placed face-up in front of him. A card shows a combination of two different colors/symbols familiar to those who know the Ingenious board game.

On a turn, the active player plays one of his hand cards and scores as many points for each symbol on the played card as there are symbols lying in front of all players. These points are marked in the matching color track on a player's individual scoring board, and the first player to have seven or more points in all colors wins. Progress is complicated by three barriers on the scoring tracks, which cannot be passed unless all colors have been bumped to a certain level of points – thereby forcing players to push their colors evenly.

As in Ingenious, players take an extra turn immediately if they max out the points available in a color, with ten being the highest number in Einfach Genial: Das Kartenspiel.

Einfach Genial: Das Kartenspiel was later released as one of three games in Fantasy Flight Games' Ingenious Challenges.

item.description:
Each player answers questions correctly in order to be the first to advance from start to finish.

There are four trivia categories: Shooting & Hunting, fishing, Camping & Survival, Potpourri.

Contents: Playing board, 2 volumes of Questions & Answers, 2 bookmarks, 2 footprint dice, 4 shotgun playing pieces, and a dice rolling cup.

Collect all 6 Island Cards and be the first traveler back to the airport. In order to collect the cards, 10 Maui Points must be gained in each of 6 sections by rolling the dice, answering questions correctly and drawing Blind Fate cards.

Contents: The Maui Game book, game board, quick start sheet, 2 dice, 24 island cards, 120 point cards, 14 transit cards, money, and 4 pineapple game pawns.
Abcdarian, a spelling game where you get a series of big words and use letters to make up smaller words out of them. Originally came with 30 words and 216 letters.

BIRTHDAY GAME PARKERS BROTHERS, INC. SALEM, MASS, NEW YORK & LONDON. Tin letters read, MADE IN SALEM, MASS. Box measures 9 1/2" x 9 1/2" x 3/4". Game features a large spinner with Zodiac Signs. More research on the game to follow. Thanks to ebayer '7onvine' for the limited info about this game.

It's a hardscrabble life for emu ranchers like yourself, raising exotic birds for foreign markets. With the high cost for every bird you hatch, it probably won't be worth it in the end. You can't tell at the beginning of the year which of the six bird varieties will do best, and beware the birds with exceptional plumage! If they thrive, they can be worth big money — but if they go wrong, they can bankrupt your ranch.

In Emu Ranchers, a Decktet game for two players, each bird on your ranch is represented by a stack of cards. Cards in a single bird stack must all share a suit and must be in rank order. At the end of the hand, the value of a bird is determined by the total of the number cards in the stack. If the total is too low, then you can end up losing money on a bird. An Ace or Crown makes the stack worth more: more profit if you can cover expenses, but more loss if you can't. The object, naturally enough, is to raise profitable birds.

item.description:
"Shake, roll, but don't get rattled in this frantic fast food race game. Be fast or be last in the whackiest, zappiest American Diner on the block!

Sunny die up, over easy, hold the fries! Take the order, serve the food and collect a tip - but its your opponent that's in control of the time with the unique, shake, rattle and roll salt pot timer. They shake - you quake, as you race to be the first player to collect three tips and win the game."

One of the last game to be produced by Waddingtons before they were taken over by Hasbro. The game is for 2-4 players, Ages 6 and up.

Each player has a coloured playing piece representing a waiter or waitress. On their turn, each player is timed using a salt pot shaker (which is effectively a timer), which is shook frantically to make the 'salt' within it drain faster. When all of the 'salt' within it reaches the bottom, the players turn is over.

During a players turn, the player may do as many of the following before their time runs out:

- roll a standard six sided die and move from the kitchen to the nearest table of their colour
- on arriving at a table, the player picks up a food order disc and tries to return to the kitchen
- upon reaching the kitchen (which contains a spinner), the player spins the spinner until it matches the food order they have picked up. The spinner can reveal either a blank or food. If food is displayed, the food order is ready
- return back from the kitchen to the table where the order was placed, and collect a money tip

The first player to collect three money tips wins.

The game board requires some assembly, and consists of the kitchen, the tables to be served, and narrow lanes which the players move along.

As with many of the later Waddingtons games, it was firmly aimed at the younger end of the market, and as a consequence has limited replay value. Still, it is fast and frantic - players are constantly rolling dice and moving pieces, whilst another player is shaking the timer to end that players turn, egged on by any other players. The narrow lanes in the board do introduce a limited amount of strategy - you can block opposing players off - and the salt pot timer is a work of genius.

A fast-paced card game where players complete and eat hot dogs as fast as they can. Collect Condiment Cards to furnish your hot dogs, but beware: other players can use Hungry Dog cards to swipe your Hot Dog Cards before you finish them. The first player to eat all of their hot dogs wins. 118 card deck.

item.description:
ROLICA AND VIMEIRO 1808 is a new module of the Jours de Gloire series, including two battles of the 1808 Campaign of Portugal (Junot against Wellesley).

Roliça and Vimeiro 1808 are the 24th and 25th battles of the Jours de Gloire series. They can be played with the Jours de Gloire Empire « Version 1808 » rules published in Vae Victis n°83 and available on the internet at http://pagesperso-orange.fr/jours.de.gloire/, where they are regularly updated.

Roliça simulates, at battalion scale, the fighting which occurred on 17 August 1808 between General Delaborde’s French division and General Wellesley’s Anglo-Portuguese army.

Vimeiro simulates, at battalion scale, the fighting which occurred on 21 August 1808 between General Junot’s French Army of Portugal and General Wellesley’s Anglo-Portuguese army.

Rules available in English or French
1 special rules and scenario booklet with historical notes and detailed OdB
2 A3x2 map - 262 counters - 1 color Player Aid Card

Tien Zi Que (TZQ) is an entertaining pocket MahJong for two. It uses a unique selection of MahJong cards, and each card has an added color code (blue, green, red, white or black) for special scoring. With exceptional game play, TZQ brings you more fun and strategy than the traditional MahJong. All you need is 5 cards on hand and little or no MahJong knowledge to play.

Tien Zi stands for son of the god, and it is also another name for the emperor of China. 
Que stands for Sparrow.

Goal / Winning the Game
After creating a Set, the winning player chooses to keep one of the cards for end of the Round scoring. When one player completes five Sets, he calls MahJong and wins the Round immediately. He then uses the one card from each Set to score. Players' points are accumulated after every winning round; the game is played to 4 rounds.

Components: 54 cards

Combines with:
Tien Zi Que: White Dragon, TZQ Red Dragon, and TZQ Green Dragon. Mix any two TZQ games for 3-4 player game, and mix any three TZQ games for 5-6 player game.

item.description: Players are moving through the Styrian Volcano-Land (a small area in the south-east of Austria) trying to buy all items on their shopping lists. This isn’t too easy since regional distributors don’t have everything and don’t have too much in stock. So sometimes it is necessary to visit a Supermarket. There it even might be cheaper but the money spent is out of the game. Money used to buy at local producers could boomerang back to the players and remains in the game. At the end of the game (two to three rounds) players check whether there is more money in the region or outside (the game). If latter one happens, all players lose together. If there’s more money in the region (on the game board) the player with the most money wins!

This is a first part of two parts game and published on the issue #41 of Game Journal in Japan.
Basically this game covers the Northern half of the Barbarossa Campaign. The period starts June 1941 and ends February 1942.
The second part was planned to be published on the issue #44 in 2006.

100 counters unmounted (you must mount it on hard-paper. Be careful because you need to mount it double-sided)
1 game map (printed on the back of the magazine thus mounted)

Basically this game covers the Southern half of the Barbarossa Campaign and could be joined with the first part simulating the whole Barbarossa Campaign. The period starts June 1941 and ends February 1942.
The first part was published on the issue #41 in 2005.

100 counters unmounted (you must mount it on hard-paper. be careful because you need to mount it double-sided)
1 game map (printed on the back of the magazine thus mounted)

name.value: The L Word Trivia Card Game

item.description:
From the box:

Think you know every shake up, break up, hang up and hook up on the sexiest show known to woman-kind? What's the first thing Bette ever said to Tina? What was Shane's stalker's name? Test your knowledge and challenge your friends on all in the ins and outs of the first two seasons.

From the Manufacturer:

You know you always wanted to run The Planet.

The Planet’s current owner is kicking off her heels and taking a well-deserved vacation. She’s looking for a protégé, someone ruthless, brilliant and sexy enough to take over while she’s gone and maybe, just maybe, become co-owner of the hottest nightspot this side of, well, the planet. Have you got the jewels to be a club owner, or will some other backstabbing tramp beat you to it?

Enkidu is a cooperative game designed by Oriol Comas i Coma, and developed by Ibermática, a Spanish enterprise.

Enkidu is a historian from the future that travels in a time machine to the past to discover a great secret. To achieve his goal, he must decode the clues hidden in Sumerian clay tiles marked with cuneiform signs.

During the game the players are characters from around the hero, and they will try to get new tiles to discover the enigma hidden in the tile. To fulfill their challenge they must compete, but also collaborate, helping each other and negotiating, as well as to take on risks and make decisions.

The game has two phases: the initiation phase to the secrets of the Sumerian Gods, and the phase of the full development of the technologies that will appear in the future.

item.description: Bilrallyspelet Monte Carlo is a game that was produced in Sweden in 1966 in cooperation with Svenska Aeroplan Aktiebolaget (SAAB) AB, the original parent company of Saab-Scania and later Saab Aerospace and the automaker Saab. The players race miniature SAAB model 96s (the car that won the Monte Carlo Rally in the early '60's, hence the name of the game and the trim package of the later model 96s) around a serpentine board, collecting bonuses and avoiding the police.
Tatu and Patu are characters in Finnish children's book series. In this game you're travelling with them around Finland and get to answer trivia questions regarding Finland.

item.description:
A childrens game to test your reflexes. But also fun to play with adults.

Every player has a hen house with nests in four different colours, each filled with 1, 2 or 3 eggs. There are two dice: one with numbers and one with colours. In the middle of the table lies the egg.
On your turn you throw both dice. Each player who has a nest that matches colour and number of eggs and still without a chicken, tries to grab the egg in the middle. If so he can put a chicken on the nest. If someone catches the egg by mistake, he has to return a hen. When the die shows a feather, the player can take a chicken from an opponent.

The first to bring nine chickens in his hen house is the winner.

Content: 4 hen houses, 36 nests, 36 hens, 2 dice, 1 egg.

name.value: Legends of the Untamed West: Blood in the Dust

item.description:
It is 1856, in the far reaches of Kansas Territory, at the base of the Rocky Mountains. Weeks ago, military authorities at (the new) Fort Bent sent out a small party of six cavalry soldiers to punish raiders for stealing sheep, kidnapping women and children, and murdering men from American settlements. But it's been too long, and the cavalry soldiers have not returned. It is your job to find them, or at least find out what happened to them.

Your first stop is the Smith settlement, one of the victims of the raiders. There you will meet Mrs. Smith and her four children and garner whatever information available.

It is now October 15, and by November 30th, you must be passing back southward through the Smith settlement to escape the raging blizzards of winter. It has already snowed in the highest mountain passes, and travel may soon be curtailed, if not shut down completely. You must move quickly, before it is too late.

Beginner: 32 point characters

name.value: Legends of Time and Space: Repel Boarders Starboard

item.description:
Legends of Time and Space: Repel Boarders Starboard is a role-playing game system of which this is a wholly contained adventure. Each player controls one or more characters who go adventuring. Players mark their characters with cardboard pieces and use a hexagon board to
depict an encounter area. One hexagon (hex) equals roughly one meter to five feet.

This adventure is driven by paragraphs and designed to be played either solitaire or with other players. If played with others, one player should be the Game Master (GM), reading the instructions aloud and keeping close track of game time and the party's current progress.

NOTE: Although the game states it has game pieces, in fact it does not. Pieces from other games in the series should be adequate or any appropriate square counters.

The colonists of a nearby planet are under sporadic attack and you are hired to pilot a small ship in to rescue them. The game includes travel and combat, both in space and man-to-man. It can be used in conjunction with other modules in the series, as the rules are fully compatible.

It can be downloaded here: http://www.darkcitygames.com/docs/RBS.pdf

This is the card game from Japan. It is published and played like President from standard deck. (information from www.Pagat.com)

The cards in this game are not same as standard deck. Number1 has 1 card, Number2 has 2 cards, Number3 has 3 cards and so on until Number13 that has 13 cards.

Component
- 91 number cards
- 9 blank cards
- 1 rules sheet (Japanese language)

For more information about President visit at PAGAT from this link http://www.pagat.com/climbing/asshole.html

Similar to:

 The Great Dalmuti
The classic game of Pictionary using a extra set (50 cards) of Hong Kong-themed words
Age of Sail is a set of tabletop combat rules for naval engagements. The rule sets allow play in these eras/settings: Ancient, Renaissance, Napoleonic, American Civil war.
Players draw letters from the box and try to create words. Instructions have different variations of the game.

name.value: The Card Game of Santa Claus

item.description: Card game where the person with the last card, Santa Clause, wins.

1972 Astronauts space game from Earl Stanza Enterprises. Players are astronauts exploring different planets within our solar system. Victory goes to the player with the most planets explored. When they reach certain planets, event cards are played to tell them what happened upon their landing.

This popular trivia game now has a junior version. Packed with fun questions that every child should know about the their country – films, books, sport, fun places to visit and much more. Answer a question correctly from each category as you move around the board and try to collect tokens. The first player to collect 6 tokens wins.

name.value: Learning Games short and long vowels

item.description: Four game boards teach vowel sounds with a nursery rhyme theme. Each game has 25 picture cards. A card is drawn and the player advances to the nearest corresponding vowel. First to reach finish wins.

Junior Obstacle Golf is an early board game offering a tabletop 9 hole golf course.

Most of the holes incorporate cardboard hazards or bunkers that stand up from the lithographed game board, for a realistic 3-D effect.

Game comes with a wooden golf club (w/ metal? head) and 4 balls. On the back of the layout sheet are the written directions for this game.

This is a shooting game where a dart like object was fired out of the hunters gun trying to knock down various targets (squirrel, owl, rabbit and others) for points. Game was produced by MADMAR QUALITY of Utica New York

name.value: The Game of Tilting the Bucket

item.description: For any number of players from British Manufacturer of Gloucester and is listed on the box as being from the "Glevum Series". You insert uprights (sort of like goal posts) firmly in the stand of division. Then you place dice in a bucket. You then shoot a marble through the aperture and try to hit the target bucket. This will "Tilt the Bucket" and cause a die to fall on one of the colored squares. You score by adding the results of where the die falls on the gameboard with the pip value on the die. Game is to 100.

Gamer's Dozen is a VHS box that comes with game system composed of 36 Plexiglas tiles, 30 glass stones, a pair of 6-sided dice and the rules for a dozen original games, most of which are roll and move games with modular boards.

The rules for the following games are included:

Muggers (2-5 players)
Movers (2-5 players)
Capture-Chase (2-5 players)
Stepping-Stones (2-5 players)
Oranges and Lemons (2-5 players)
Horse Race (2-6 players)
Pot-Shots (2-5 players)
Thinker's Dice (2-6 players)
Orange Rush (2-4 players)
Homeland Security (3-6 players)
Mover's Maze (2-4 players)
Apex (2-4 players)

Take a tour on the Washington Wine Trails! Friends and Family will enjoy gathering to play an exciting new game from Mind Games LLC. Beautifully illustrated and educational! Visit tasting rooms to complete your wine collection, but be careful not to commit a faux-pas! Includes over 200 cards with information on wine tasting, food pairing, and even what not to do on a wine tour.

The object of the game is to be the player with the most prestige. Throughout the game the player will be exploring different wine trails, building prestige, completing a wine cellar, and even committing Faux-Pas. Any player who completes the game with at least one accomplishment on their party card sheet, with the most prestige points, wins the game.

Home Page: http://www.washingtonwinetrails.com

"Gentlemen, start your engines!" Going The Distance is a fast-paced, speed vs. damage and consequences racing game. Do you red-line your car and risk blowing your engine, or do you subscribe to the theory "slow and steady wins the race"? Do you take the corners sharply, risking a spin-out or worse, a blow-out? Will you pit and repair or go for broke on the hopes your car holds out? The choices are yours to make. Going The Distance combines the edge of your seat thrills of auto racing with easy, yet strategic, boardgame mechanics.

Going the Distance is a dice-driven auto racing game. Each player controls up to three cars that have mechanical and tire attributes recorded on a roster sheet. The players elect to roll between three and five specially marked six-sided die to generate movement and maneuver for each phase of a turn. Unique to this racing game is an "all move" portion of the turn sequence where all cars advance on a designated six-sided die roll.

The game can use either stock cars or open wheeled racing cars as playing pieces.

item.description: This is a three dimensional (you can also play flat in just 2 dimensions as well) crossword game. Players take turns building their words, much like Scrabble with no board and in 3 dimensions. Connectors are used when you plan to go vertical (which also changes the orientation 90 degrees).

Fast-paced, trivia-laced, fun entertainment for the whole family. The objective is to race to “the brain”. With a flurry of flashing lights and sounds, the 3-D brain randomly chooses one of six categories. Then you choose one of three difficulty levels. Watch out – board events can quickly change the destiny of the game, so it takes more than brains to win. Great for developing thinking and social skills. For 2 to 4 players, play a long or short version. Includes game board, electronic brain, 280 question cards, 4 playing pieces, 2 dice. Requires 2 AA batteries, not included. Ages 9 and up

Roll Domo Roll is a dice game in which you score points my rolling certain dice combinations. You can also lose points with a bad roll. You can earn extra points(or lose points) by making side bets against other players

From the manufacturer:
 
 A daring high-risk, high-reward dice game featuring Domo, Mr. Usaji, and Tashanna. Roll the dice and make high scoring combinations that you keep track of on the game board. You may keep rolling and try to increase your earnings, but watch out! If you roll an apple, you lose everything you just won.

name.value: Thiet Giap, the struggle for An Loc (2008)
Thiet Giap, the struggle for An Loc (1972)

item.description:
An LPS bonus mini-game.

April 1972; a Young US Army captain watched a stream of ARVN fugitives screaming "Thiet Giap!" ; "Tank!" in Vietnamese. He climbs on a roof top to see what is happening and spots a column of dark green T54 tanks advancing. The Battle of An Loc had just began.

The Peoples Army of (North) Vietnam had launched its biggest offensive of the war. Hundred of tanks, artillery pieces and ten of thousands of trained and confident infantrymen launched a 4 prong attack on the Republic of Vietnam. From Cambodia 3 Divisions descend along the Ropute Nationale 13 toward Saigon. At the small town of An Loc a ragtag band of dispirited ARVN infantrymen, elite rangers and paratroopers stood fast. What was supposed to be a victorious blitzkrieg toward Saigon evolved in a protracted slugfest with B52, American airpower, airmobile assaults and tank charges. In the end the shattered remains of the 3 PAVN divisions run back toward Cambodia leaving only a shattered mass of ruins, but a defiant and victorious garrison.

Using regiment and battalion sized units, airpower, artillery, tanks and an operation system that reward increasing the tempo of battle Thiet Giap simulates the battle for the Town of An Loc and the relief effort made by ARVN troops to break the siege. T54 tanks, B52, Paratroopers and sappers are included.

One 11x17" map and <100 counters.
